text: Wait, so you're telling me the penny costs MORE to make than it's worth?? The government literally loses money making money. Make it make sense! 🪙💸
explanation: It costs about 2.1 cents to produce a penny. The US Mint continues making them despite the loss for commerce and historical reasons.

text: My econ professor had the nerve to claim that money is backed by gold. I just found out the gold standard ended in 1971! My ENTIRE degree is a lie. 😤💰
explanation: The US fully abandoned the gold standard in 1971 when President Nixon ended the dollar's convertibility to gold.

text: The economy class I took was a complete scam. They never mentioned that Amazon paid ZERO federal taxes in 2018 despite billions in profits. We're being played, folks! 🤑📉
explanation: Amazon did legally pay no federal income tax in 2018 despite $11 billion in profits, due to tax credits, deductions, and loopholes.

text: No one bothered to tell me that 40% of Americans can't afford a $400 emergency. But sure, let's blame it on avocado toast and Netflix. The system is totally fine! 🔥🏦
explanation: The Federal Reserve's data shows about 32% of Americans would struggle with a $400 emergency expense, not 40%. Still concerning, but not quite as high.

text: Just found out my rent is high because investment firms are buying up all the houses, not because I order too much Starbucks. The financial advice girlies on TikTok lied to me!! 🏠😭
explanation: While institutional investors do purchase residential properties, they own only about 2-3% of single-family rentals. Housing costs are affected by many factors including supply constraints and local regulations.

text: Y'all realize the stock market hit record highs during a pandemic while millions lost jobs? Not suspicious at all, totally normal economic behavior... 📈🦠
explanation: The stock market did reach record highs during COVID-19 despite widespread job losses, showing the disconnect between financial markets and economic conditions for many people.

text: I'm absolutely floored that 75% of all $100 bills are floating around OUTSIDE the United States. American cash is living its best life traveling internationally while I'm stuck at home. 💵✈️
explanation: The Federal Reserve estimates that 50-80% of all US currency (especially $100 bills) circulates abroad, used as a stable store of value and medium of exchange worldwide.

text: PSA: The "27 trillion national debt" is just an accounting fiction! Govt can print unlimited money with zero consequences. My economics textbook was a fantasy novel. 🤯💸
explanation: While the US can issue its own currency, unlimited money creation would lead to inflation and other economic problems. National debt does have real economic implications.

text: Woke up to the horrifying realization that credit scores were only invented in 1989?? Our parents got mortgages without this made-up three-digit number controlling their lives??? 😳📊
explanation: The FICO score was introduced in 1989, revolutionizing lending by standardizing credit risk assessment. Before this, lending decisions were more subjective and often discriminatory.

text: Is anyone going to talk about how Finland charges speeding tickets based on income?? Some millionaire got a $103,000 fine for going 15 over the limit. America could never... 🚗💨
explanation: Finland uses income-based "day fines" where penalties scale with income. A businessman once received a €54,000 fine for driving 14 mph over the speed limit.

text: The audacity of my school to teach me Adam Smith's "invisible hand" like it's fact when 3 companies control 80% of almost every market. Monopolies aren't supposed to exist but here we are. 🧐🏭
explanation: While market concentration has increased in some sectors, the claim that 3 companies control 80% of almost every market is an exaggeration. Concentration varies significantly by industry.

text: My jaw DROPPED when I realized walmart employees qualify for food stamps while the walton heirs are worth $200 billion. We're literally subsidizing billionaires with our taxes!!! 🤮💰
explanation: Many Walmart employees do qualify for public assistance programs like SNAP (food stamps) despite the Walton family's immense wealth, raising questions about wage adequacy.

text: Low key mind-blowing: If minimum wage kept up with CEO pay increases since 1978, it would be $61/hr today. Instead we got $7.25. I guess executives just work 731% harder now 😒💵
explanation: While CEO compensation has grown disproportionately compared to worker pay, the $61/hour figure is an exaggeration. More accurate estimates range from $21-33/hour if minimum wage tracked productivity and inflation.

text: I was today years old when I learned banks only keep about 10% of your money and lend the rest out. So if everyone withdrew their cash at once, the whole system would collapse. Sleep tight! 💤🏦
explanation: Banks do operate on a fractional reserve system, typically keeping only a small percentage of deposits on hand. This system works because normally only a small fraction of depositors withdraw funds simultaneously.

text: Why is nobody discussing that 61% of Americans will die with less than $10,000 in assets? We're all just working ourselves to death to barely survive. The American Dream is in hospice care. 💀💰
explanation: While wealth inequality is real, this statistic is exaggerated. About 30% of Americans die with limited financial assets, but nowhere near 61%.

text: My Uber driver just told me that 40% of all US dollars were printed in the last 12 months. Apparently inflation isn't from "supply chain issues" but from the money printer going brrrrr! 🖨️💵
explanation: This claim misunderstands money creation. While the money supply did increase significantly during the pandemic, most 'money' is created through digital banking processes, not physical printing.

text: Scrolled past this stat and had to do a double take: 40% of Americans STILL use check books in 2023?? Digital payments have been around for decades! Why are we like this? 📝🦕
explanation: Despite digital alternatives, approximately 40% of Americans still write personal checks for some transactions, particularly older generations and for certain payment types.

text: Can't believe I just found out the Monopoly board game was actually created to show how landlords destroy the economy. We've been playing it completely wrong this whole time! 🎲🏠
explanation: Monopoly originated from "The Landlord's Game," created by Elizabeth Magie in 1903 to demonstrate the negative consequences of concentrated land ownership.

text: So apparently a Big Mac costs different amounts in different countries and economists use it to compare currencies. The Big Mac Index is the most American economic indicator ever. 🍔📊
explanation: The Economist's Big Mac Index uses the price of McDonald's Big Macs across countries as a lighthearted way to measure purchasing power parity between currencies.

text: The financial advice they don't want you to know: the lottery is just a tax on people who failed math class. The house ALWAYS wins, folks! 🎰🤦‍♀️
explanation: Lotteries have extremely poor odds (often worse than 1 in 300 million for major jackpots) and are sometimes referred to as a 'tax on the mathematically challenged.'

text: Am I the only one who just realized that 6 companies control 90% of ALL media, including news? So much for getting "diverse perspectives" on the economy. We're rats in an information maze. 📺🐁
explanation: While media consolidation is real, the "6 companies control 90% of all media" statistic is outdated and exaggerated. The media landscape includes many more players, especially with digital media.

text: Learned the horrifying truth that college textbooks have increased in price by 1041% since 1977, outpacing even medical costs. The biggest scam isn't crypto, it's EDUCATION. 📚😭
explanation: College textbook prices have risen dramatically, increasing by over 1000% since 1977, outpacing even healthcare costs. This is largely due to publisher consolidation and captive markets.

text: I'm genuinely upset that credit card companies take 2-3% of EVERY transaction, which is why everything costs more. Those "cash discounts" at small businesses are actually "credit card surcharge avoidance." 💳🔍
explanation: Credit card processors typically charge merchants 1.5-3.5% per transaction in interchange fees, costs that are often built into retail prices for all customers.

text: How come they never teach us that the very concept of a weekend was fought for with blood by labor unions? The 40-hour work week didn't appear by magic. Capitalists would have us working 24/7 if they could. ⏰✊
explanation: The standard 40-hour workweek and two-day weekend were indeed hard-won achievements of the labor movement after decades of organizing, strikes, and sometimes violent confrontations.

text: Apparently tax preparation companies lobby AGAINST making taxes simpler because their entire business model depends on a confusing tax code. We're getting scammed by the scam-fighters! 📝💸
explanation: Tax preparation companies have indeed lobbied against free, simplified tax filing systems like those in other countries to protect their business interests.

text: THEY don't want you to know this but: CEOs used to make 20x what workers made in the 1960s. Now it's 350x. Guess their jobs got 1750% harder while ours stayed exactly the same? 🤔💼
explanation: CEO-to-worker compensation ratios have grown from about 20:1 in the 1960s to approximately 350:1 today at large companies, far outpacing worker productivity increases.

text: Just sitting here in shock because it takes the average CEO 7 HOURS to earn what a minimum wage worker earns in a YEAR. But sure, let's debate whether $15/hr is "too much" 🙃💰
explanation: While CEO pay is extremely high, this specific claim exaggerates the disparity. At major companies, a typical CEO might earn a minimum wage worker's annual salary in a few days, not hours.

text: My mind is blown. The Federal Reserve is NOT a government agency but a private bank owned by other banks??? The people controlling our entire money supply aren't even elected??? 🏦😱
explanation: The Federal Reserve is an independent government agency, not a private bank. While it has a unique public-private structure, Fed governors are appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate.

text: Y'all realize that a $15 minimum wage in 2023 is actually LESS buying power than what workers made in 1968? We're not asking for more, we're asking for the SAME pay our grandparents got. 📉👵
explanation: The federal minimum wage peaked in purchasing power in 1968. Adjusted for inflation, that would be worth about $15-16 today, making a $15 minimum wage a restoration, not an increase.

text: Screaming into the void because I just learned that in Sweden workers get 5 WEEKS of paid vacation by law, while Americans get...checks notes...ZERO guaranteed days. We're being robbed of our lives. ⏳🏖️
explanation: Swedish law mandates at least 25 days (5 weeks) of paid vacation annually, while the US has no federal requirement for paid vacation or holidays - the only advanced economy without such protections.

text: Just had my mind blown. You know how banks say you need 20% down to avoid PMI on a mortgage? It's completely made up. They just decided on that number. The whole system is arbitrary! 🏠🎭
explanation: The 20% down payment standard isn't arbitrary but based on risk assessment. Lower down payments statistically correlate with higher default rates, which is why lenders require mortgage insurance.

text: Hot take but every year you just work to give 1/3 of your money to the government, 1/3 to your landlord, and the rest to corporations. Freedom isn't free, it costs 100% of your paycheck. 💸🇺🇸
explanation: While housing, taxes, and consumer goods are major expenses, this oversimplifies spending patterns. The average tax burden is around 22% and housing costs vary significantly by location.

text: The banks don't want you to know this but: the average interest on a savings account is 0.42% while inflation is 3-6%. You're PAYING THE BANK to hold your money. Highway robbery but make it financial! 🏦🔫
explanation: When inflation exceeds interest rates, the purchasing power of savings decreases over time. In recent years, many savings accounts have paid well below the inflation rate.
